AvailableVariables

Source: vignettes/AvailableVariables.Rmd
AvailableVariables.Rmd

medusa allows for the calculation of distributional impacts according to numerous socio-economic and demographic variables of households. The variables for which the package currently works are detailed and described below.

Variable Description Labels
QUINTIL The quintile variable distributes households into 5 groups according to their income [1], with 1 representing the poorest households in the distribution and 5 the richest. 1-5
DECIL The decile variable distributes households into 10 groups according to their income [1], with 1 representing the poorest households in the distribution and 10 the richest. 1-10
VENTIL The variable ventil distributes households into 20 groups according to their income [1], with 1 representing the poorest households in the distribution and 20 the richest. 1-20
PERCENTIL The percentile variable distributes households into 100 groups according to their income [1], with 1 representing the poorest households in the distribution and 100 the richest. 1-100
CCAA Autonomous Community of residence of the household (NUTS2). Andalucía
Aragón
Asturias
Baleares
Canarias
Cantabria
Castilla y León
Castilla La Mancha
Cataluña
Comunidad Valenciana
Extremadura
Galicia
Madrid
Murcia
Navarra
País Vasco
La Rioja
Ceuta
Melilla
TAMAMU Size of municipality of residence. >10.000: Municipalities with more than 10,000 inhabitants
<10.000: Small municipality with less than 10,000 inhabitants
ZONA Level of rurality of the household’s area of residence Urbana: densely populated urban area
Semiurbana: semiurban area with an intermediate population density
Rural: rural area with a low population density
TIPHOGAR Household type. Personas mayores solas: Elderly alone
Personas solas: Single person
Monoparental: Single parent
Parejas mayores: Elderly couples
Parejas sin hijos/as: Couples without children
Parejas con hijos/as: Couples with children
Parejas con hijos/as: Couples with children
Parejas con hijos/as: Couples with children
Monoparental: Single parent
Parejas con hijos/as: Couples with children
Otros: Others
HIJOS Number of household members under 18 years. Sin hijos/as: No children
Con hijos/as: With 1 or 2 children
Familia numerosa: Large family with 3 or more children
POBREZA The household is at risk of poverty if its income [1] is below 60% of the national median. En riesgo: At risk of poverty
Sin riesgo: without risk of falling into poverty
GENEROPR Gender of the reference person of the household. Hombre: when the household reference person is a man
Mujer: when the household reference person is a woman
GRADOFEM Feminization degree of the household. FD1: households in which less than 20% of the household members are women
FD2:households in which 20-40% of the household members are female
FD3:households in which 40-60% of the household members are female
FD4:households in which 60-80% of the household members are female
FD5: households in which more than 80% of the household members are women
EDADPR Age of the reference person in the household. The age is calculated as at the date of completion of the household file. Joven: Young person aged 30 years or less
Persona adulta: Adult person between 30 and 65 years of age
Persona mayor: Elderly person aged 65 years or more
PAISPR Country of birth of the reference person of the household. España: when the reference person in the household was born in Spain
UE27: when the reference person of the household was born in an EU27 country (excluding Spain)
Otros Europa: when the reference person of the household was born in a European country outside the EU27
Resto mundo: when the reference person of the household was born in a country in the rest of the world, i.e. in a non-European country
ESTUDIOSPR Education level completed by the reference person of the household. Sin estudios: Without studies
Primaria: Primary education
ESO: Secondary education
Bachiller-FP: Post-secondary non tertiary education
Superiores: Higher education
SPROFESIONALPR Professional status of the reference person of the household. Asalariada: Employee
Autonoma: Self-employed
Empleadora: Employer
Otros: Others
No aplica: Do not apply
TIPOCONTPR Type of employment contract of the reference person of the household. Indefinido: Indefinite contract
Temporal: Temporary contract
No aplica: Do not apply
JORNADAPR Working hours of the reference person of the household. Completa: Full time
Parcial: Part time
No aplica: Do not apply
REGIMENVP Tenure status of the household’s main residence. Propiedad: with home ownership with or without mortgage
Alquiler: with rented housing
Cesión: ……

[1]Equivalent consumption expenditure is used instead of income as it is considered a better proxy for permanent household income since it fluctuates less in the long run (Goodman & Oldfield, 2004). The equivalent spending is calculated based on household spending relativized by the modified OECD equivalence scale, thus considering the economies of scale generated in households based on their size. The modified OECD scale values 1 for the reference person in the household, 0.5 for other people aged 14 or over, and 0.3 for other people under 14 years of age.

[R1] Goodman, A., & Oldfield, Z. (2004). Permanent differences? Income and expenditure inequality in the 1990s and 2000s (Research Report R66). IFS Report. https://doi.org/10.1920/re.ifs.2004.0066

Developed by Eva Alonso-Epelde, Clàudia Rodés-Bachs, María Moyano-Reina, Jon Sampedro, Xaquín García-Muros.
